Description: catchment identifier (8-digit USGS hydrologic unit code)
region (2-digit USGS hydrologic unit code)
gauge name, followed by the state
gauge latitude
gauge longitude
catchment mean elevation
catchment mean slope
catchment area (GAGESII estimate)
catchment area (Geospatial Fabric estimate)
mean daily precipitation
mean daily PET [estimated by N15 using Priestley-Taylor formulation calibrated for each catchment]
aridity (PET/P, ratio of mean PET [estimated by N15 using Priestley-Taylor formulation calibrated for each catchment] to mean precipitation)

seasonality and timing of precipitation (estimated using sine curves to represent the annual temperature and preciptiation cycles, positive [negative] values indicate that precipitation peaks in summer [winter], values close to 0 indicate uniform precipitation throughout the year)
fraction of precipitation falling as snow (i.e. on days colder than 0°C)
frequency of high precipitation days ( >= 5 times mean daily precip.)
average duration of high precipitation events (number of consecutive days >= 5 times mean daily precip.)
season during which most high precipitation days ( >= 5 times mean daily precip.) occur
average frequency of dry days ( <1 mm/day)
average duration of dry periods (number of consecutive days <1 mm/day)
season during which most dry days ( <1 mm/day) occur
mean discharge
runoff ratio (ratio of long-term average streamflow to long-term average precipitation)
streamflow elasticity (sensitivity of streamflow to changes in precipitation at the annual time scale, using the long-term average as reference)
References: Eq. 7 in Sankarasubramanian et al. (2001), the last element being P/Q not Q/P

Description: slope of the flow duration curve (between the log-transformed 33rd and 66th streamflow percentiles)
baseflow index (ratio of long-term average baseflow to long-term average streamflow, hydrograph separation performed using Ladson et al. [2013] digital filter)
References: Eq. 4 in Sawicz et al. (2011), Ladson et al. (2013)

Description: mean half flow date (date on which the cumulative discharge since October 1st reaches half of the annual discharge)
5% flow quantile
95% flow quantile
average frequency of high flow days ( > 9 times the median daily flow)
References: Clausen and Biggs (2000), Table 2 in Westerberg and McMillan (2015)

Description: average duration of high flow events (number of consecutive days > 9 times the median daily flow)
References: Clausen and Biggs (2000), Table 2 in Westerberg and McMillan (2015)

Description: average frequency of daily low-flow days ( < 0.2 times mean daily flow)
References: Olden and Poff (2003), Table 2 in Westerberg and McMillan (2015)

Description: average duration of daily flow events (number of consecutive days < 0.2 times the mean daily flow)
References: Olden and Poff (2003), Table 2 in Westerberg and McMillan (2015)

Description: frequency of days with Q = 0
forest fraction
maximum monthly mean of the leaf area index (based on 12 monthly means)
difference between the maximum and mimumum monthly mean of the leaf area index (based on 12 monthly means)
maximum monthly mean of the green vegetation fraction (based on 12 monthly means)
difference between the maximum and mimumum monthly mean of the green vegetation fraction (based on 12 monthly means)
dominant land cover (Noah-modified 20-category IGBP-MODIS land cover)
fraction of the catchment area associated with the dominant land cover
root depth (percentiles XX = 50% extracted from a root depth distribution based on IGBP land cover)
root depth (percentiles XX = 99% extracted from a root depth distribution based on IGBP land cover)
depth to bedrock (maximum 50m)
soil depth (maximum 1.5m, layers marked as water and bedrock were excluded)

volumetric porosity (saturated volumetric water content estimated using a multiple linear regression based on sand and clay fraction for the layers marked as USDA soil texture class and a default value [0.9] for layers marked as organic material, layers marked as water, bedrock and "other" were excluded)
References: Table 4 in Cosby et al. (1984), Lawrence and Slater (2008)

Description: saturated hydraulic conductivity (estimated using a multiple linear regression based on sand and clay fraction for the layers marked as USDA soil texture class and a default value [36cm/hr] for layers marked as organic material, layers marked as water, bedrock and "other" were excluded)
References: Table 4 in Cosby et al. (1984), Lawrence and Slater (2008)

Description: maximum water content (combination of porosity and soil_depth_statgso, layers marked as water, bedrock and "other" were excluded)
sand fraction (of the soil material smaller than 2 mm, layers marked as oragnic material, water, bedrock and "other" were excluded)
silt fraction (of the soil material smaller than 2 mm, layers marked as oragnic material, water, bedrock and "other" were excluded)
clay fraction (of the soil material smaller than 2 mm, layers marked as oragnic material, water, bedrock and "other" were excluded)
fraction of the top 1.5m marked as water (class 14 )
fraction of soil_depth_statgso marked as organic material (class 13)
fraction of soil_depth_statgso marked as other (class 16)
most common geologic class in the catchment
fraction of the catchment area associated with its most common geologic class
2nd most common geologic class in the catchment
fraction of the catchment area associated with its 2nd most common geologic class
fraction of the catchment area characterized as "Carbonate sedimentary rocks"
subsurface porosity
subsurface permeability (log10)
